title: China Development Bank provides a $5 million USD loan to the Development Bank of Jamaica for on-lending purposes
description: In 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) and the Development Bank of Jamaica (DBJ) signed a $5 million loan agreement for on-lending to projects that involved the purchase of goods and services from China. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 5 years and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus 380 basis points. This loan was repaid in full by December 2014.
staff_comments: 1. This CDB loan is not included in the China-Latin America Finance Database, which is co-produced by the Inter-American Dialogue and Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center. 2. The Development Bank of Jamaica is a corporation wholly owned by the Government of Jamaica and is mandated to foster economic growth and development of strategic sectors of the Jamaican economy. 3. The 6-Month LIBOR rate is not identified in any of the underlying sources, so AidData used the average 6-Month LIBOR rate from 2011 (0.507%) to calculate the effective, all-in interest rate (0.507% + 3.800% = 4.307%).
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
China Development Bank provides a $5 million USD loan to the Development Bank of Jamaica for on-lending purposes

# Description
In 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) and the Development Bank of Jamaica (DBJ) signed a $5 million loan agreement for on-lending to projects that involved the purchase of goods and services from China. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 5 years and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus 380 basis points. This loan was repaid in full by December 2014.
justification: Loan agreement for on-lending purposes without specific environmental or energy transition focus
evidence: General financial services loan, no specified project types or environmental impacts

title: China's CHEC donates J$300,000 to the Christiana High School daCosta Cup football team
description: In 2011, China Harbour Engineering Company donated $300,000 Jamaican dollars donation to the Christiana High School daCosta Cup football team for their purchase of gear and other items needed to compete.  The school was located adjacent to their Christiana Development Road JDIP project, so CHEC granted their request as part of their corporate social responsibility policy.

justification: Project is a social development initiative unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Donation to school football team for gear and equipment, part of corporate social responsibility

title: CHEC donates shower wheelchairs and adult diapers to Golden Age Home in Kingston
description: On December 23rd, 2011, China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) donated 24 shower wheelchairs and several boxes of adult diapers to the Golden Age Home in Kingston, Jamaica. Present at the donation handover was CHEC regional director, Zhongdong Tang. According to media reports, the donation was worth J$450,000.   The Golden Age home is an elder care facility in Kingston, Jamaica. At the time of the donation, it had 450 residents.

title: CHEC donates a motorcycle to Spring Hill Police
description: On November 3rd, 2011, China Harbour Engineering Co. and Stewart's Auto Sales Ltd. collaborated to each donate a motorcycle to the Spring Hill Police Station in Portland Parish, Jamaica. Present at the donation handover were Qi Wu Yang, CHEC's Jamaica deputy manager; J. Stewart-Lechler, director of Stewart's Auto Sales; Owen Ellington, commissioner of police; and Daryl Vaz, member of parliament.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 75 million grant for Phase 1 of Russaifah Water Network Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#41242 and ID#64723)
description: On March 18, 2007, China's Ambassador to Jordan, Gong Xiaosheng, and Jordan's Minister of Planning and International Cooperation, Suhair Al Ali, signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) regarding a potential RMB 50 million grant for Phase 1 of the Russaifah Water Network Reconstruction Project. However, in April 2009, China’s Ministry of Commerce issued a contract to Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group worth RMB 75 million for the implementation of this project. The grant proceeds that were used to finance this contract were reportedly drawn from three different Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreements (ETCAs) that the Chinese Government and the Government of Jordan previously signed: one in June 2004, another in June 2005, and a third in November 2011.   This project involved the construction or reconstruction of nearly 150 km of water supply pipes — including 17.38 km of water distribution main pipes, 88.01 km of water distribution branch pipes, and 44.94 km of hospital inlet pipes — in Russaifiah (Russeifa or لواء الرصيفة) District within Jordan’s northeastern Zarqa Governorate. Its ultimate purpose was to improve the provision of potable water and the living standards of 70,000 residents in Russaifiah District.   Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group was the contractor responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on April 14, 2010. However, project implementation did not begin until May 20, 2010. MOFCOM conducted a mid-term project inspection in August 2011. The project was ultimately completed on 2012. According to Jordan's Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation, the Chinese Government ultimately disbursed $7.5 million support of this project. The Chinese Government also funded Phase 2 of the Russaifah Water Network Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#64723).
staff_comments: This project is also known as Phase 1 of the Russaifah Water Network Project, Phase 1 of the Water Supply Network Upgrading and Expansion Project, the First Phase of the Ruseifa Water Network Project, and the Rehabilitation and Expansion of Water Supply Networks in Russaifah District. The Chinese project title is 鲁萨伊法供水网改造项目 or 约旦供水网改造工程第一阶段项目 or 约旦供水网改造项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 75 million grant for Phase 1 of Russaifah Water Network Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#41242 and ID#64723)

# Description
On March 18, 2007, China's Ambassador to Jordan, Gong Xiaosheng, and Jordan's Minister of Planning and International Cooperation, Suhair Al Ali, signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) regarding a potential RMB 50 million grant for Phase 1 of the Russaifah Water Network Reconstruction Project. However, in April 2009, China’s Ministry of Commerce issued a contract to Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group worth RMB 75 million for the implementation of this project. The grant proceeds that were used to finance this contract were reportedly drawn from three different Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreements (ETCAs) that the Chinese Government and the Government of Jordan previously signed: one in June 2004, another in June 2005, and a third in November 2011.   This project involved the construction or reconstruction of nearly 150 km of water supply pipes — including 17.38 km of water distribution main pipes, 88.01 km of water distribution branch pipes, and 44.94 km of hospital inlet pipes — in Russaifiah (Russeifa or لواء الرصيفة) District within Jordan’s northeastern Zarqa Governorate. Its ultimate purpose was to improve the provision of potable water and the living standards of 70,000 residents in Russaifiah District.   Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group was the contractor responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on April 14, 2010. However, project implementation did not begin until May 20, 2010. MOFCOM conducted a mid-term project inspection in August 2011. The project was ultimately completed on 2012. According to Jordan's Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation, the Chinese Government ultimately disbursed $7.5 million support of this project. The Chinese Government also funded Phase 2 of the Russaifah Water Network Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#64723).
justification: Project focuses on water supply infrastructure improvement without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction/reconstruction of water supply pipes, focus on improving potable water provision and living standards

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 18 million grant for Establishment and Equipping of Civil Defense Stations Project
description: On November 21, 2011, China’s Ministry of Commerce and Jordan's Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation signed an RMB 18,000,000 grant agreement for the provision of firefighting machinery and equipment to the Jordanian Civil Defense Directorate. The grant proceeds were apparently drawn from two Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments previously signed in 2008.   This project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on December 8, 2011. The Chinese Ambassador to Jordan, Yue Xiaoyong, and the Jordanian Director General of Civil Defense, Major General Talal Abdullah al Kofahi, attended the handover ceremony. The equipment and machinery was earmarked for use in Abdali (العبدلي‎), which is an area within the Greater Amman Municipality.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 18 million grant for Establishment and Equipping of Civil Defense Stations Project

# Description
On November 21, 2011, China’s Ministry of Commerce and Jordan's Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation signed an RMB 18,000,000 grant agreement for the provision of firefighting machinery and equipment to the Jordanian Civil Defense Directorate. The grant proceeds were apparently drawn from two Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments previously signed in 2008.   This project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on December 8, 2011. The Chinese Ambassador to Jordan, Yue Xiaoyong, and the Jordanian Director General of Civil Defense, Major General Talal Abdullah al Kofahi, attended the handover ceremony. The equipment and machinery was earmarked for use in Abdali (العبدلي‎), which is an area within the Greater Amman Municipality.
justification: Project focuses on civil defense and public safety infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of firefighting machinery and equipment for civil defense stations, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Hanban funds establishment of Confucius Institute at Philadelphia University in Amman
description: On September 25, 2011, Hanban signed an agreement with Philadelphia University (جامعة فيلادلفيا) in Amman, committing to establish a Confucius Institute at the university in cooperation with Liaocheng University. The center is about 500 square meters and employs three Chinese language teachers. The purpose of this project was to teach Chinese language and culture to Jordanian students while deepening cultural exchanges and relations between the two countries.   On September 16, 2012 the Confucius Institute's name plaque was unveiled. On April 10, 2013, the Confucius Institute at the University of Philadelphia was officially opened and it began operations. Staf Note: Documents provided by the Chinese Embassy in Jordan differ on the precise date of the opening ceremony. A summary report of the opening ceremony records the date as April 10, 2013, while a speech given by Ambassador Yue Xiaoyang at the opening ceremony is dated September 19, 2012. The University of Philadelphia's website indicates that the unveiling of the center's name plaque took place in 2012 while it operations began in 2013.
staff_comments: Documents provided by the Chinese Embassy in Jordan differ on the date of the opening ceremony. A summary report of the opening ceremony records the date as April 10th, 2013, while a speech given by Ambassador Yue Xiaoyang at the opening ceremony is dated September 19th, 2012. The University of Philadelphia's website however, indicates that the unveiling of the center's name plaque took place in 2012 while  operations began in 2013.
combined_text:

The center is about 500 square meters and employs three Chinese language teachers. The purpose of this project was to teach Chinese language and culture to Jordanian students while deepening cultural exchanges and relations between the two countries.   On September 16, 2012 the Confucius Institute's name plaque was unveiled. On April 10, 2013, the Confucius Institute at the University of Philadelphia was officially opened and it began operations. Staf Note: Documents provided by the Chinese Embassy in Jordan differ on the precise date of the opening ceremony. A summary report of the opening ceremony records the date as April 10, 2013, while a speech given by Ambassador Yue Xiaoyang at the opening ceremony is dated September 19, 2012. The University of Philadelphia's website indicates that the unveiling of the center's name plaque took place in 2012 while it operations began in 2013.
justification: Project focuses on cultural and educational exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute for Chinese language and culture education, cultural exchange focus

title: Chinese Government provides $1.9 million grant for Jordanian Gendarmerie Equipment Project
description: In 2011, the Chinese Government donated equipment to the General Directorate of Gendarmerie otherwise known as the Darak Forces (المديرية العامة لقوات الدرك), a public security agency which is part of the Jordanian Ministry of the Interior. The monetary value of this equipment was $1,900,000.

In 2011, the Chinese Government donated equipment to the General Directorate of Gendarmerie otherwise known as the Darak Forces (المديرية العامة لقوات الدرك), a public security agency which is part of the Jordanian Ministry of the Interior. The monetary value of this equipment was $1,900,000.

title: Chinese Ministry of Culture provides RMB 200,000 grant for provision of audio and lighting equipment to the Jordanian Ministry of Culture
description: On July 12th, 2011 the Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China granted audio and lighting equipment valued at CNY 200,000 Yuan to the Jordanian Ministry of Culture. The equipment was officially handed over at a signing ceremony on the same day, attended by the Chinese Charge d’affaires, Chen Xinzhong, and Jordanian Minister of Culture, Jeles Samavi.   According to the Chinese Embassy in Jordan the project was intended to deepen cultural relations between Jordan and China. The Jordanian Ministry of Culture distributed the equipment to various Governorates outside the capital for use during cultural activities as "mobile" equipment.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Ministry of Culture provides RMB 200,000 grant for provision of audio and lighting equipment to the Jordanian Ministry of Culture

# Description
On July 12th, 2011 the Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China granted audio and lighting equipment valued at CNY 200,000 Yuan to the Jordanian Ministry of Culture. The equipment was officially handed over at a signing ceremony on the same day, attended by the Chinese Charge d’affaires, Chen Xinzhong, and Jordanian Minister of Culture, Jeles Samavi.   According to the Chinese Embassy in Jordan the project was intended to deepen cultural relations between Jordan and China. The Jordanian Ministry of Culture distributed the equipment to various Governorates outside the capital for use during cultural activities as "mobile" equipment.
justification: Project focuses on cultural exchange and equipment provision without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of audio and lighting equipment for cultural activities, aimed at deepening cultural relations

title: China Development Bank provides RMB 1 billion loan for Aktogay Copper Mine Development Project (Linked to Project ID#41941 and #53580)
description: On June 13, 2011, Kazykhmys PLC (now called KAZ Minerals PLC) signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with China Development Bank (CDB) for a $1.5 billion loan to develop its Aktogay Copper Mine Project. Then, on December 16, 2011, CDB signed two bilateral facility (loan) agreements with KAZ Minerals Aktogay Finance Limited — a special purpose vehicle and wholly-owned subsidiary of KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP, which is itself a wholly-owned subsidiary of Kazykhmys PLC (Kaz Minerals PLC) — for the Aktogay Copper Mine Development Project: an RMB 1 billion ($158 million) loan agreement (as captured via Project ID#39557) and a $1.34 billion loan agreement (as captured via Project ID#41941). The RMB 1 billion loan tranche (facility) and the $1.34 billion loan tranche (facility) were available to the borrower for draw down over a three year period. The maturity of each loan was 15 years from the date of first draw down and the grace period of each loan was 3 years. The interest rate for the USD-denominated loan tranche was LIBOR plus a 4.20% margin and the interest rate for the RMB-denominated loan tranche was based on the applicable benchmark lending rate published by the People's Bank of China (PBoC). KAZ Minerals PLC provided a guarantee for both loans. As an additional credit enhancement, the borrower pledged a $100,000,000 minimum cash balance in a charge account (collection account) as a source of collateral.  As of December 31, 2015, the RMB facility was fully drawn down (disbursed). To protect against currency risks, KAZ Minerals swapped the interest basis from a RMB interest rate into a USD LIBOR interest basis. As of December 31, 2016, the USD facility was fully drawn down. Arrangement fees with an amortized cost of $15 million, were netted off against these borrowings in accordance with IAS 39. The USD facility was repayable in half-yearly installments beginning in March 2018.  The 2016 audited KAZ Minerals financial report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.12% and 4.33% (as of December 31, 2016) and 5.12% and 3.93% (as December 31, 2015), respectively. The 2017 report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.60% and 4.54% (as of December 31, 2017) respectively. AidData has used this information to estimate the interest rates that apply to these loans.    The initial development cost of the copper mine was $2 billion, with KAZ Minerals seeking to fund the remaining $500 million. The mine was eventually expected to produce up to 100,000 tons of copper concentrate annually beginning in 2015. The project was comprised of an open-pit mine and an on-site concentrator to produce copper cathode from oxide ore and copper concentrate from the sulphide ore, with molybdenum as a by-product. Alarko was the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor responsible for the processing plant at Aktogay. BIR provided engineering and consultancy services for architectural, civil, mechanical and electrical works for the project. ABB provided complete electrification and automation solutions and three gearless mill drive systems, while Ausenco was contracted to work on the open-pit mine. China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was awarded the contract for the construction of the sulphide concentrator. Construction began in 2013). Copper cathode production from oxide began on December 1, 2015. CDB would later commit $300 million in 2016 specifically for the construction of the sulphide concentrator by NFC, as captured via Project ID#53580.
staff_comments: 1. The bank account pledge agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/07rf5n70hulk1by/Aktogay%202019%20Account%20Charge%20Agreement.pdf?dl=0
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Development Bank provides RMB 1 billion loan for Aktogay Copper Mine Development Project (Linked to Project ID#41941 and #53580)

# Description
On June 13, 2011, Kazykhmys PLC (now called KAZ Minerals PLC) signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with China Development Bank (CDB) for a $1.5 billion loan to develop its Aktogay Copper Mine Project. Then, on December 16, 2011, CDB signed two bilateral facility (loan) agreements with KAZ Minerals Aktogay Finance Limited — a special purpose vehicle and wholly-owned subsidiary of KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP, which is itself a wholly-owned subsidiary of Kazykhmys PLC (Kaz Minerals PLC) — for the Aktogay Copper Mine Development Project: an RMB 1 billion ($158 million) loan agreement (as captured via Project ID#39557) and a $1.34 billion loan agreement (as captured via Project ID#41941). The RMB 1 billion loan tranche (facility) and the $1.34 billion loan tranche (facility) were available to the borrower for draw down over a three year period. The maturity of each loan was 15 years from the date of first draw down and the grace period of each loan was 3 years. The interest rate for the USD-denominated loan tranche was LIBOR plus a 4.20% margin and the interest rate for the RMB-denominated loan tranche was based on the applicable benchmark lending rate published by the People's Bank of China (PBoC). KAZ Minerals PLC provided a guarantee for both loans. As an additional credit enhancement, the borrower pledged a $100,000,000 minimum cash balance in a charge account (collection account) as a source of collateral.  As of December 31, 2015, the RMB facility was fully drawn down (disbursed). To protect against currency risks, KAZ Minerals swapped the interest basis from a RMB interest rate into a USD LIBOR interest basis. As of December 31, 2016, the USD facility was fully drawn down. Arrangement fees with an amortized cost of $15 million, were netted off against these borrowings in accordance with IAS 39. The USD facility was repayable in half-yearly installments beginning in March 2018.  The 2016 audited KAZ Minerals financial report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.12% and 4.33% (as of December 31, 2016) and 5.12% and 3.93% (as December 31, 2015), respectively. The 2017 report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.60% and 4.54% (as of December 31, 2017) respectively. AidData has used this information to estimate the interest rates that apply to these loans.    The initial development cost of the copper mine was $2 billion, with KAZ Minerals seeking to fund the remaining $500 million. The mine was eventually expected to produce up to 100,000 tons of copper concentrate annually beginning in 2015. The project was comprised of an open-pit mine and an on-site concentrator to produce copper cathode from oxide ore and copper concentrate from the sulphide ore, with molybdenum as a by-product. Alarko was the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor responsible for the processing plant at Aktogay. BIR provided engineering and consultancy services for architectural, civil, mechanical and electrical works for the project. ABB provided complete electrification and automation solutions and three gearless mill drive systems, while Ausenco was contracted to work on the open-pit mine. China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was awarded the contract for the construction of the sulphide concentrator. Construction began in 2013). Copper cathode production from oxide began on December 1, 2015. CDB would later commit $300 million in 2016 specifically for the construction of the sulphide concentrator by NFC, as captured via Project ID#53580.
justification: Project focuses on copper mining, which is a critical mineral for energy transition technologies
evidence: Copper mine development, production of copper concentrate and cathode, molybdenum by-product
